name: Selfoss Waterfall - Dettifoss's Upstream Neighbor
description: Selfoss is a beautifully elegant horseshoe-shaped waterfall on Iceland's powerful Jökulsá á Fjöllum river (the nation's second-longest river at 206 kilometers), located just one kilometer upstream from the famous Dettifoss in Vatnajökull National Park in North Iceland. While its downstream neighbor Det tifoss claims the title of Europe's most powerful waterfall with its massive 44-meter plunge, Selfoss offers a different type of beauty: a graceful 11-meter (36-foot) drop that spreads across approximately 100 meters (330 feet) of width in a distinctive V-shaped or horseshoe configuration that splits the glacial river into multiple silvery cascades flowing over curved basalt ledges. The waterfall's shape creates numerous individual streams and channels that weave around dark volcanic rock formations, producing a complex, layered appearance that many visitors find more aesthetically pleasing and photogenic than Dettifoss's raw brute power. The Jökulsá á Fjöllum river that feeds Selfoss originates as meltwater from Vatnajökull glacier (Europe's largest ice cap), giving the water a characteristic milky-gray color from suspended glacial sediment and ensuring powerful flow volumes that vary seasonally with temperature and weather conditions affecting glacial melting. Selfoss sits within the dramatic Jökulsárgljúfur canyon, a massive geological feature carved by catastrophic glacial floods and ongoing river erosion, with steep rock walls rising on both sides creating an amphitheater effect around the falls.
address: Jökulsárgljúfur, Vatnajökull National Park, North Iceland

opening_hours.access_season: Late May to September (roads closed in winter)
